column2: Morality is satisfied; but let us not congratulate the Spider therefore. If the invader respects the invaded, it is because very serious reasons impel her.
column3: Morality is satisfied; but let us not congratulate the Spider therefore. If the invader respects the invaded, it is because very serious reasons impel her.

column2: First, she would have to contend with an adversary ensconced in a stronghold whose ambushes are unknown to the assailant.
column3: First, she would have to contend with an adversary ensconced in a stronghold whose ambushes are unknown to the assailant.

column2: Secondly, the web, if conquered, would be inconvenient to use, because of the lime- threads, possessing a different degree of stickiness from those which she knows so well.
column3: Secondly, the web, if conquered, would be inconvenient to use, because of the lime threads, possessing a different degree of stickiness from those which she knows so well.

column2: To risk one's skin for a thing of doubtful value were twice foolish.

column2: The Spider knows this and forbears.
column3: The Spider knows this and forbears.

column2: But let the Banded Epeira, deprived of her web, come upon that of one of her kind or of the Silky Epeira, who works her gummy twine in the same manner: then discretion is thrown to the winds; the owner is fiercely ripped open and possession taken of the property.
column3: But let the Banded Epeira, deprived of her web, come upon that of one of her kind or of the Silky Epeira, who works her gummy twine in the same manner: then discretion is thrown to the winds; the owner is fiercely ripped open and possession taken of the property.

column2: Might is right, says the beast; or, rather, it knows no right.
column3: Might is right, says the beast; or, rather, it knows no right.

column2: The animal world is a rout of appetites, acknowledging no other rein than impotence.
column3: The animal world is a rout of appetites, acknowledging no other rein than impotence.

column2: Mankind, alone capable of emerging from the slough of the instincts, is bringing equity into being, is creating it slowly as its conception grows clearer.
column3: Mankind, alone capable of emerging from the slough of the instincts, is bringing equity into being, is creating it slowly as its conception grows clearer.

column2: Out of the sacred rushlight, so flickering as yet, but gaining strength from age to age, man will make a flaming torch that will put an end, among us, to the principles of the brutes and, one day, utterly change the face of society.
column3: Out of the sacred rushlight, so flickering as yet, but gaining strength from age to age, man will make a flaming torch that will put an end, among us, to the principles of the brutes and, one day, utterly change the face of society.

column2: CHAPTER XV: THE LABYRINTH SPIDER
column3: CHAPTER fifteen: THE LABYRINTH SPIDER

column2: While the Epeirae, with their gorgeous net-tapestries, are incomparable weavers, many other Spiders excel in ingenious devices for filling their stomachs and leaving a lineage behind them: the two primary laws of living things.
column3: While the Epeirae, with their gorgeous net tapestries, are incomparable weavers, many other Spiders excel in ingenious devices for filling their stomachs and leaving a lineage behind them: the two primary laws of living things.

column2: Some of them are celebrities of long-standing renown, who are mentioned in all the books.
column3: Some of them are celebrities of long-standing renown, who are mentioned in all the books.

column2: Certain Mygales {36} inhabit a burrow, like the Narbonne Lycosa, but of a perfection unknown to the brutal Spider of the waste-lands.
column3: Certain Mygales {thirty six} inhabit a burrow, like the Narbonne Lycosa, but of a perfection unknown to the brutal Spider of the waste lands.

column2: The Lycosa surrounds the mouth of her shaft with a simple parapet, a mere collection of tiny pebbles, sticks and silk; the others fix a movable door to theirs, a round shutter with a hinge, a groove and a set of bolts.
column3: The Lycosa surrounds the mouth of her shaft with a simple parapet, a mere collection of tiny pebbles, sticks and silk; the others fix a movable door to theirs, a round shutter with a hinge, a groove and a set of bolts.

column2: When the Mygale comes home, the lid drops into the groove and fits so exactly that there is no possibility of distinguishing the join.
column3: When the Mygale comes home, the lid drops into the groove and fits so exactly that there is no possibility of distinguishing the join.

column2: If the aggressor persist and seek to raise the trap-door, the recluse pushes the bolt, that is to say, plants her claws into certain holes on the opposite side to the hinge, props herself against the wall and holds the door firmly.
column3: If the aggressor persist and seek to raise the trap door, the recluse pushes the bolt, that is to say, plants her claws into certain holes on the opposite side to the hinge, props herself against the wall and holds the door firmly.

column2: Another, the Argyroneta, or Water Spider, builds herself an elegant silken diving-bell, in which she stores air.
column3: Another, the Argyroneta, or Water Spider, builds herself an elegant silken diving bell, in which she stores air.

column2: Thus supplied with the wherewithal to breathe, she awaits the coming of the game and keeps herself cool meanwhile.
column3: Thus supplied with the wherewithal to breathe, she awaits the coming of the game and keeps herself cool meanwhile.

column2: At times of scorching heat, hers must be a regular sybaritic abode, such as eccentric man has sometimes ventured to build under water, with mighty blocks of stone and marble.
column3: At times of scorching heat, hers must be a regular sybaritic abode, such as eccentric man has sometimes ventured to build under water, with mighty blocks of stone and marble.

column3: The submarine palaces of Tiberius are no more than an odious memory; the Water Spider's dainty cupola still flourishes.

column3: If I possessed documents derived from personal observation, I should like to speak of these ingenious workers; I would gladly add a few unpublished facts to their life history.

column2: But I must abandon the idea.
column3: But I must abandon the idea.

column2: The Water Spider is not found in my district.
column3: The Water Spider is not found in my district.

column2: The Mygale, the expert in hinged doors, is found there, but very seldom.
column3: The Mygale, the expert in hinged doors, is found there, but very seldom.

column3: I saw one once, on the edge of a path skirting a copse.

column2: Opportunity, as we know, is fleeting.
column3: Opportunity, as we know, is fleeting.

column2: The observer, more than any other, is obliged to take it by the forelock. Preoccupied as I was with other researches, I but gave a glance at the magnificent subject which good fortune offered.

column2: Let us make up for it with trivial things of frequent encounter, a condition favourable to consecutive study.
column3: Let us make up for it with trivial things of frequent encounter, a condition favourable to consecutive study.

column2: What is common is not necessarily unimportant.
column3: What is common is not necessarily unimportant.

column2: Give it our sustained attention and we shall discover in it merits which our former ignorance prevented us from seeing.
column3: Give it our sustained attention and we shall discover in it merits which our former ignorance prevented us from seeing.

column2: When patiently entreated, the least of creatures adds its note to the harmonies of life.
column3: When patiently entreated, the least of creatures adds its note to the harmonies of life.

column2: In the fields around, traversed, in these days, with a tired step, but still vigilantly explored, I find nothing so often as the Labyrinth Spider (_Agelena labyrinthica_, CLERCK.).
column3: In the fields around, traversed, in these days, with a tired step, but still vigilantly explored, I find nothing so often as the Labyrinth Spider (underscore Agelena labyrinthica underscore, CLERCK.).

column2: Not a hedge but shelters a few at its foot, amidst grass, in quiet, sunny nooks.
column3: Not a hedge but shelters a few at its foot, amidst grass, in quiet, sunny nooks.

column2: In the open country and especially in hilly places laid bare by the wood-man's axe, the favourite sites are tufts of bracken, rock-rose, lavender, everlasting and rosemary cropped close by the teeth of the flocks.
column3: In the open country and especially in hilly places laid bare by the wood man's axe, the favourite sites are tufts of bracken, rock rose, lavender, everlasting and rosemary cropped close by the teeth of the flocks.

column2: This is where I resort, as the isolation and kindliness of the supports lend themselves to proceedings which might not be tolerated by the unfriendly hedge.
column3: This is where I resort, as the isolation and kindliness of the supports lend themselves to proceedings which might not be tolerated by the unfriendly hedge.

column2: Several times a week, in July, I go to study my Spiders on the spot, at an early hour, before the sun beats fiercely on one's neck.
column3: Several times a week, in July, I go to study my Spiders on the spot, at an early hour, before the sun beats fiercely on one's neck.

column2: The children accompany me, each provided with an orange wherewith to slake the thirst that will not be slow in coming.
column3: The children accompany me, each provided with an orange wherewith to slake the thirst that will not be slow in coming.

column2: They lend me their good eyes and supple limbs.
column3: They lend me their good eyes and supple limbs.

column2: The expedition promises to be fruitful.
column3: The expedition promises to be fruitful.

column2: We soon discover high silk buildings, betrayed at a distance by the glittering threads which the dawn has converted into dewy rosaries.
column3: We soon discover high silk buildings, betrayed at a distance by the glittering threads which the dawn has converted into dewy rosaries.

column2: The children are wonderstruck at those glorious chandeliers, so much so that they forget their oranges for a moment.
column3: The children are wonderstruck at those glorious chandeliers, so much so that they forget their oranges for a moment.

column2: Nor am I, on my part, indifferent.
column3: Nor am I, on my part, indifferent.

column2: A splendid spectacle indeed is that of our Spider's labyrinth, heavy with the tears of the night and lit up by the first rays of the sun.
column3: A splendid spectacle indeed is that of our Spider's labyrinth, heavy with the tears of the night and lit up by the first rays of the sun

column2: Accompanied as it is by the Thrushes' symphony, this alone is worth getting up for.
column3: Accompanied as it is by the Thrushes' symphony, this alone is worth getting up for.

column2: Half an hour's heat; and the magic jewels disappear with the dew.
column3: Half an hour's heat; and the magic jewels disappear with the dew.

column2: Now is the moment to inspect the webs.
column3: Now is the moment to inspect the webs.

column2: Here is one spreading its sheet over a large cluster of rock-roses; it is the size of a handkerchief.
column3: Here is one spreading its sheet over a large cluster of rock roses; it is the size of a handkerchief.

column2: A profusion of guy-ropes, attached to any chance projection, moor it to the brushwood.
column3: A profusion of guy ropes, attached to any chance projection, moor it to the brushwood.

column2: There is not a twig but supplies a contact-point.
column3: There is not a twig but supplies a contact point.

column2: Entwined on every side, surrounded and surmounted, the bush disappears from view, veiled in white muslin.
column3: Entwined on every side, surrounded and surmounted, the bush disappears from view, veiled in white muslin.

column2: The web is flat at the edges, as far as the unevenness of the support permits, and gradually hollows into a crater, not unlike the bell of a hunting-horn.
column3: The web is flat at the edges, as far as the unevenness of the support permits, and gradually hollows into a crater, not unlike the bell of a hunting horn.

column2: The central portion is a cone-shaped gulf, a funnel whose neck, narrowing by degrees, dives perpendicularly into the leafy thicket to a depth of eight or nine inches.
column3: The central portion is a cone shaped gulf, a funnel whose neck, narrowing by degrees, dives perpendicularly into the leafy thicket to a depth of eight or nine inches.

column2: At the entrance to the tube, in the gloom of that murderous alley, sits the Spider, who looks at us and betrays no great excitement at our presence.
column3: At the entrance to the tube, in the gloom of that murderous alley, sits the Spider, who looks at us and betrays no great excitement at our presence.

column2: She is grey, modestly adorned on the thorax with two black ribbons and on the abdomen with two stripes in which white specks alternate with brown.
column3: She is grey, modestly adorned on the thorax with two black ribbons and on the abdomen with two stripes in which white specks alternate with brown.

column2: At the tip of the belly, two small, mobile appendages form a sort of tail, a rather curious feature in a Spider.
column3: At the tip of the belly, two small, mobile appendages form a sort of tail, a rather curious feature in a Spider.

column2: The crater-shaped web is not of the same structure throughout.
column3: The crater shaped web is not of the same structure throughout.

column2: At the borders, it is a gossamer weft of sparse threads; nearer the centre, the texture becomes first fine muslin and then satin; lower still, on the narrower part of the opening, it is a network of roughly lozenged meshes. Lastly, the neck of the funnel, the usual resting-place, is formed of solid silk.
column3: At the borders, it is a gossamer weft of sparse threads; nearer the centre, the texture becomes first fine muslin and then satin; lower still, on the narrower part of the opening, it is a network of roughly lozenged meshes. Lastly, the neck of the funnel, the usual resting place, is formed of solid silk.

column2: The Spider never ceases working at her carpet, which represents her investigation-platform.
column3: The Spider never ceases working at her carpet, which represents her investigation platform.

column2: Every night she goes to it, walks over it, inspecting her snares, extending her domain and increasing it with new threads.
column3: Every night she goes to it, walks over it, inspecting her snares, extending her domain and increasing it with new threads.

column2: The work is done with the silk constantly hanging from the spinnerets and constantly extracted as the animal moves about.
column3: The work is done with the silk constantly hanging from the spinnerets and constantly extracted as the animal moves about.

column2: The neck of the funnel, being more often walked upon than the rest of the dwelling, is therefore provided with a thicker upholstery.
column3: The neck of the funnel, being more often walked upon than the rest of the dwelling, is therefore provided with a thicker upholstery.

column2: Beyond it are the slopes of the crater, which are also much-frequented regions.
column3: Beyond it are the slopes of the crater, which are also much frequented regions.

column2: Spokes of some regularity fix the diameter of the mouth; a swaying walk and the guiding aid of the caudal appendages have laid lozengy meshes across these spokes.
column3: Spokes of some regularity fix the diameter of the mouth; a swaying walk and the guiding aid of the caudal appendages have laid lozengy meshes across these spokes.

column2: This part has been strengthened by the nightly rounds of inspection.

column2: Lastly come the less-visited expanses, which consequently have a thinner carpet.
column3: Lastly come the less visited expanses, which consequently have a thinner carpet.

column2: At the bottom of the passage dipping into the brushwood, we might expect to find a secret cabin, a wadded cell where the Spider would take refuge in her hours of leisure.
column3: At the bottom of the passage dipping into the brushwood, we might expect to find a secret cabin, a wadded cell where the Spider would take refuge in her hours of leisure.

column3: The reality is something entirely different. The long funnel neck gapes at its lower end, where a private door stands always ajar, allowing the animal, when hard pushed, to escape through the grass and gain the open.

column2: It is well to know this arrangement of the home, if you wish to capture the Spider without hurting her.
column3: It is well to know this arrangement of the home, if you wish to capture the Spider without hurting her.

column3: When attacked from the front, the fugitive runs down and slips through the postern gate at the bottom.

column3: To look for her by rummaging in the brushwood often leads to nothing, so swift is her flight; besides, a blind search entails a great risk of maiming her.

column2: Let us eschew violence, which is but seldom successful, and resort to craft.

column2: We catch sight of the Spider at the entrance to her tube.
column3: We catch sight of the Spider at the entrance to her tube.

column2: If practicable, squeeze the bottom of the tuft, containing the neck of the funnel, with both hands.
column3: If practicable, squeeze the bottom of the tuft, containing the neck of the funnel, with both hands.

column2: That is enough; the animal is caught.
column3: That is enough; the animal is caught.

column3: Feeling its retreat cut off, it readily darts into the paper bag held out to it; if necessary, it can be stimulated with a bit of straw.

column2: In this way, I fill my cages with subjects that have not been demoralized by contusions.

column2: The surface of the crater is not exactly a snare.
column3: The surface of the crater is not exactly a snare.

column3: It is just possible for the casual pedestrian to catch his legs in the silky carpets; but giddy pates who come here for a walk must be very rare.

column2: What is wanted is a trap capable of securing the game that hops or flies.

column2: The Epeira has her treacherous limed net; the Spider of the bushes has her no less treacherous labyrinth.
column3: The Epeira has her treacherous limed net; the Spider of the bushes has her no less treacherous labyrinth.

column2: Look above the web.
column3: Look above the web.

column2: What a forest of ropes!
column3: What a forest of ropes!

column2: It might be the rigging of a ship disabled by a storm.

column2: They run from every twig of the supporting shrubs, they are fastened to the tip of every branch.

column3: There are long ropes and short ropes, upright and slanting, straight and bent, taut and slack, all criss cross and a tangle, to the height of three feet or so in inextricable disorder.

column3: The different webs which I inspect to study the food in the larder show me, among other joints, various Flies and small Butterflies and carcasses of almost untouched Locusts, all deprived of their hind legs, or at least of one.

column3: The bite is a lingering one: once the Spider has planted her fangs, she does not let go.

column3: When this first point is drained, she passes on to others, to the second haunch in particular, until the prey becomes an empty hulk without losing its outline.

column2: Although it lasts long, the meal is eaten in perfect safety.

column3: The Spider knows right well; I am in the dark.

column2: The insect, in its buildings, has its own architectural rules, rules as unchangeable as anatomical peculiarities.
column3: The insect, in its buildings, has its own architectural rules, rules as unchangeable as anatomical peculiarities.

column2: Each group builds according to the same set of principles, conforming to the laws of a very elementary system of aesthetics; but often circumstances beyond the architect's control--the space at her disposal, the unevenness of the site, the nature of the material and other accidental causes--interfere with the worker's plans and disturb the structure.
column3: Each group builds according to the same set of principles, conforming to the laws of a very elementary system of aesthetics; but often circumstances beyond the architect's control-the space at her disposal, the unevenness of the site, the nature of the material and other accidental causes-interfere with the worker's plans and disturb the structure.

column2: Then virtual regularity is translated into actual chaos; order degenerates into disorder.
column3: Then virtual regularity is translated into actual chaos; order degenerates into disorder.

column2: We might discover an interesting subject of research in the type adopted by each species when the work is accomplished without hindrances.
column3: We might discover an interesting subject of research in the type adopted by each species when the work is accomplished without hindrances.

column2: The Banded Epeira weaves the wallet of her eggs in the open, on a slim branch that does not get in her way; and her work is a superbly artistic jar. The Silky Epeira also has all the elbow-room she needs; and her paraboloid is not without elegance.
column3: The Banded Epeira weaves the wallet of her eggs in the open, on a slim branch that does not get in her way; and her work is a superbly artistic jar. The Silky Epeira also has all the elbow room she needs; and her paraboloid is not without elegance.

column2: Can the Labyrinth Spider, that other spinstress of accomplished merit, be ignorant of the precepts of beauty when the time comes for her to weave a tent for her offspring?
column3: Can the Labyrinth Spider, that other spinstress of accomplished merit, be ignorant of the precepts of beauty when the time comes for her to weave a tent for her offspring?

column2: As yet, what I have seen of her work is but an unsightly bundle.
column3: As yet, what I have seen of her work is but an unsightly bundle.

column2: Is that all she can do?
column3: Is that all she can do?

column2: I look for better things if circumstances favour her.
column3: I look for better things if circumstances favour her.

column2: Toiling in the midst of a dense thicket, among a tangle of dead leaves and twigs, she may well produce a very inaccurate piece of work; but compel her to labour when free from all impediment: she will then--I am convinced of it beforehand--apply her talents without constraint and show herself an adept in the building of graceful nests.
column3: Toiling in the midst of a dense thicket, among a tangle of dead leaves and twigs, she may well produce a very inaccurate piece of work; but compel her to labour when free from all impediment: she will then-I am convinced of it beforehand-apply her talents without constraint and show herself an adept in the building of graceful nests.

column2: As laying-time approaches, towards the middle of August, I instal half-a- dozen Labyrinth Spiders in large wire-gauze cages, each standing in an earthen pan filled with sand.
column3: As laying time approaches, towards the middle of August, I instal half a dozen Labyrinth Spiders in large wire gauze cages, each standing in an earthen pan filled with sand.

column2: A sprig of thyme, planted in the centre, will furnish supports for the structure, together with the trellis-work of the top and sides.
column3: A sprig of thyme, planted in the centre, will furnish supports for the structure, together with the trellis work of the top and sides.

column2: There is no other furniture, no dead leaves, which would spoil the shape of the nest if the mother were minded to employ them as a covering.
column3: There is no other furniture, no dead leaves, which would spoil the shape of the nest if the mother were minded to employ them as a covering.

column2: By way of provision, Locusts, every day.
column3: By way of provision, Locusts, every day.

column2: They are readily accepted, provided they be tender and not too large.
column3: They are readily accepted, provided they be tender and not too large.

column2: The experiment works perfectly.
column3: The experiment works perfectly.

column2: August is hardly over before I am in possession of six nests, magnificent in shape and of a dazzling whiteness.
column3: August is hardly over before I am in possession of six nests, magnificent in shape and of a dazzling whiteness.

column2: The latitude of the workshop has enabled the spinstress to follow the inspiration of her instinct without serious obstacles; and the result is a masterpiece of symmetry and elegance, if we allow for a few angularities demanded by the suspension-points.
column3: The latitude of the workshop has enabled the spinstress to follow the inspiration of her instinct without serious obstacles; and the result is a masterpiece of symmetry and elegance, if we allow for a few angularities demanded by the suspension points.

column2: It is an oval of exquisite white muslin, a diaphanous abode wherein the mother must make a long stay to watch over the brood.
column3: It is an oval of exquisite white muslin, a diaphanous abode wherein the mother must make a long stay to watch over the brood.

column2: The size is nearly that of a Hen's egg.
column3: The size is nearly that of a Hen's egg.

column2: The cabin is open at either end.
column3: The cabin is open at either end.

column2: The front-entrance broadens into a gallery; the back-entrance tapers into a funnel-neck.
column3: The front entrance broadens into a gallery; the back entrance tapers into a funnel neck.

column2: I fail to see the object of this neck.
column3: I fail to see the object of this neck.

column2: As for the opening in front, which is wider, this is, beyond a doubt, a victualling-door.
column3: As for the opening in front, which is wider, this is, beyond a doubt, a victualling door.

column2: I see the Spider, at intervals, standing here on the look-out for the Locust, whom she consumes outside, taking care not to soil the spotless sanctuary with corpses.
column3: I see the Spider, at intervals, standing here on the look out for the Locust, whom she consumes outside, taking care not to soil the spotless sanctuary with corpses.

column2: The structure of the nest is not without a certain similarity to that of the home occupied during the hunting-season.
column3: The structure of the nest is not without a certain similarity to that of the home occupied during the hunting season.

column2: The passage at the back represents the funnel-neck, that ran almost down to the ground and afforded an outlet for flight in case of grave danger.
column3: The passage at the back represents the funnel neck, that ran almost down to the ground and afforded an outlet for flight in case of grave danger.

column2: The one in front, expanding into a mouth kept wide open by cords stretched backwards and forwards, recalls the yawning gulf into which the victims used to fall. Every part of the old dwelling is repeated: even the labyrinth, though this, it is true, is on a much smaller scale.
column3: The one in front, expanding into a mouth kept wide open by cords stretched backwards and forwards, recalls the yawning gulf into which the victims used to fall. Every part of the old dwelling is repeated: even the labyrinth, though this, it is true, is on a much smaller scale.

column2: In front of the bell-shaped mouth is a tangle of threads wherein the passers-by are caught.
column3: In front of the bell shaped mouth is a tangle of threads wherein the passers by are caught.

column2: Each species, in this way, possesses a primary architectural model which is followed as a whole, in spite of altered conditions.
column3: Each species, in this way, possesses a primary architectural model which is followed as a whole, in spite of altered conditions.

column2: The animal knows its trade thoroughly, but it does not know and will never know aught else, being incapable of originality.
column3: The animal knows its trade thoroughly, but it does not know and will never know aught else, being incapable of originality.

column2: Now this palace of silk, when all is said, is nothing more than a guard- house.
column3: Now this palace of silk, when all is said, is nothing more than a guard house.

column2: Behind the soft, milky opalescence of the wall glimmers the egg- tabernacle, with its form vaguely suggesting the star of some order of knighthood.
column3: Behind the soft, milky opalescence of the wall glimmers the egg tabernacle, with its form vaguely suggesting the star of some order of knighthood.

column2: It is a large pocket, of a splendid dead-white, isolated on every side by radiating pillars which keep it motionless in the centre of the tapestry.
column3: It is a large pocket, of a splendid dead white, isolated on every side by radiating pillars which keep it motionless in the centre of the tapestry.

column2: These pillars are about ten in number and are slender in the middle, expanding at one end into a conical capital and at the other into a base of the same shape.
column3: These pillars are about ten in number and are slender in the middle, expanding at one end into a conical capital and at the other into a base of the same shape.

column2: They face one another and mark the position of the vaulted corridors which allow free movement in every direction around the central chamber.
column3: They face one another and mark the position of the vaulted corridors which allow free movement in every direction around the central chamber.

column2: The mother walks gravely to and fro under the arches of her cloisters, she stops first here, then there; she makes a lengthy auscultation of the egg-wallet; she listens to all that happens inside the satin wrapper.
column3: The mother walks gravely to and fro under the arches of her cloisters, she stops first here, then there; she makes a lengthy auscultation of the egg wallet; she listens to all that happens inside the satin wrapper.

column2: To disturb her would be barbarous.
column3: To disturb her would be barbarous.

column2: For a closer examination, let us use the dilapidated nests which we brought from the fields.
column3: For a closer examination, let us use the dilapidated nests which we brought from the fields.

column2: Apart from its pillars, the egg-pocket is an inverted conoid, reminding us of the work of the Silky Epeira.
column3: Apart from its pillars, the egg pocket is an inverted conoid, reminding us of the work of the Silky Epeira.

column2: Its material is rather stout; my pincers, pulling at it, do not tear it without difficulty.
column3: Its material is rather stout; my pincers, pulling at it, do not tear it without difficulty.

column2: Inside the bag there is nothing but an extremely fine, white wadding and, lastly, the eggs, numbering about a hundred and comparatively large, for they measure a millimetre and a half.
column3: Inside the bag there is nothing but an extremely fine, white wadding and, lastly, the eggs, numbering about a hundred and comparatively large, for they measure a millimetre and a half.

column2: {37} They are very pale amber-yellow beads, which do not stick together and which roll freely as soon as I remove the swan's-down shroud.
column3: {thirty seven} They are very pale amber yellow beads, which do not stick together and which roll freely as soon as I remove the swan's down shroud.

column2: Let us put everything into a glass-tube to study the hatching.
column3: Let us put everything into a glass tube to study the hatching.

column2: We will now retrace our steps a little.
column3: We will now retrace our steps a little.

column2: When laying-time comes, the mother forsakes her dwelling, her crater into which her falling victims dropped, her labyrinth in which the flight of the Midges was cut short; she leaves intact the apparatus that enabled her to live at her ease. Thoughtful of her natural duties, she goes to found another establishment at a distance.
column3: When laying time comes, the mother forsakes her dwelling, her crater into which her falling victims dropped, her labyrinth in which the flight of the Midges was cut short; she leaves intact the apparatus that enabled her to live at her ease. Thoughtful of her natural duties, she goes to found another establishment at a distance.

column2: Why at a distance?
column3: Why at a distance?

column2: She has still a few long months to live and she needs nourishment.
column3: She has still a few long months to live and she needs nourishment.

column2: Were it not better, then, to lodge the eggs in the immediate neighbourhood of the present home and to continue her hunting with the excellent snare at her disposal?
column3: Were it not better, then, to lodge the eggs in the immediate neighbourhood of the present home and to continue her hunting with the excellent snare at her disposal?

column2: The watching of the nest and the easy acquisition of provender would go hand in hand.
column3: The watching of the nest and the easy acquisition of provender would go hand in hand.

column2: The Spider is of another opinion; and I suspect the reason.
column3: The Spider is of another opinion; and I suspect the reason.

column2: The sheet-net and the labyrinth that surmounts it are objects visible from afar, owing to their whiteness and the height whereat they are placed.
column3: The sheet net and the labyrinth that surmounts it are objects visible from afar, owing to their whiteness and the height whereat they are placed.

column2: Their scintillation in the sun, in frequented paths, attracts Mosquitoes and Butterflies, like the lamps in our rooms and the fowler's looking-glass.
column3: Their scintillation in the sun, in frequented paths, attracts Mosquitoes and Butterflies, like the lamps in our rooms and the fowler's looking glass.

column2: Whoso comes to look at the bright thing too closely dies the victim of his curiosity.
column3: Whoso comes to look at the bright thing too closely dies the victim of his curiosity.

column2: There is nothing better for playing upon the folly of the passer-by, but also nothing more dangerous to the safety of the family.
column3: There is nothing better for playing upon the folly of the passer by, but also nothing more dangerous to the safety of the family.

column2: Harpies will not fail to come running at this signal, showing up against the green; guided by the position of the web, they will assuredly find the precious purse; and a strange grub, feasting on a hundred new-laid eggs, will ruin the establishment.
column3: Harpies will not fail to come running at this signal, showing up against the green; guided by the position of the web, they will assuredly find the precious purse; and a strange grub, feasting on a hundred new laid eggs, will ruin the establishment.

column2: I do not know these enemies, not having sufficient materials at my disposal for a register of the parasites; but, from indications gathered elsewhere, I suspect them.
column3: I do not know these enemies, not having sufficient materials at my disposal for a register of the parasites; but, from indications gathered elsewhere, I suspect them.

column2: The Banded Epeira, trusting to the strength of her stuff, fixes her nest in the sight of all, hangs it on the brushwood, taking no precautions whatever to hide it.
column3: The Banded Epeira, trusting to the strength of her stuff, fixes her nest in the sight of all, hangs it on the brushwood, taking no precautions whatever to hide it.

column2: And a bad business it proves for her.
column3: And a bad business it proves for her.

column2: Her jar provides me with an Ichneumon {38} possessed of the inoculating larding- pin: a _Cryptus_ who, as a grub, had fed on Spiders' eggs.
column3: Her jar provides me with an Ichneumon {thirty eight} possessed of the inoculating larding pin: a underscore Cryptus underscore who, as a grub, had fed on Spiders' eggs.

column2: Nothing but empty shells was left inside the central keg; the germs were completely exterminated.
column3: Nothing but empty shells was left inside the central keg; the germs were completely exterminated.

column2: There are other Ichneumon-flies, moreover, addicted to robbing Spiders' nests; a basket of fresh eggs is their offspring's regular food.
column3: There are other Ichneumon flies, moreover, addicted to robbing Spiders' nests; a basket of fresh eggs is their offspring's regular food.

column2: Like any other, the Labyrinth Spider dreads the scoundrelly advent of the pickwallet; she provides for it and, to shield herself against it as far as possible, chooses a hiding-place outside her dwelling, far removed from the tell-tale web.
column3: Like any other, the Labyrinth Spider dreads the scoundrelly advent of the pickwallet; she provides for it and, to shield herself against it as far as possible, chooses a hiding place outside her dwelling, far removed from the tell tale web.

column2: When she feels her ovaries ripen, she shifts her quarters; she goes off at night to explore the neighbourhood and seek a less dangerous refuge.
column3: When she feels her ovaries ripen, she shifts her quarters; she goes off at night to explore the neighbourhood and seek a less dangerous refuge.

column2: The points selected are, by preference, the low brambles dragging along the ground, keeping their dense verdure during the winter and crammed with dead leaves from the oaks hard by.
column3: The points selected are, by preference, the low brambles dragging along the ground, keeping their dense verdure during the winter and crammed with dead leaves from the oaks hard by.

column2: Rosemary- tufts, which gain in thickness what they lose in height on the unfostering rock, suit her particularly.
column3: Rosemary tufts, which gain in thickness what they lose in height on the unfostering rock, suit her particularly.

column2: This is where I usually find her nest, not without long seeking, so well is it hidden.
column3: This is where I usually find her nest, not without long seeking, so well is it hidden.

column2: So far, there is no departure from current usage.
column3: So far, there is no departure from current usage.

column2: As the world is full of creatures on the prowl for tender mouthfuls, every mother has her apprehensions; she also has her natural wisdom, which advises her to establish her family in secret places.
column3: As the world is full of creatures on the prowl for tender mouthfuls, every mother has her apprehensions; she also has her natural wisdom, which advises her to establish her family in secret places.

column2: Very few neglect this precaution; each, in her own manner, conceals the eggs she lays.
column3: Very few neglect this precaution; each, in her own manner, conceals the eggs she lays.

column2: In the case of the Labyrinth Spider, the protection of the brood is complicated by another condition.
column3: In the case of the Labyrinth Spider, the protection of the brood is complicated by another condition.

column2: In the vast majority of instances, the eggs, once lodged in a favourable spot, are abandoned to themselves, left to the chances of good or ill fortune.
column3: In the vast majority of instances, the eggs, once lodged in a favourable spot, are abandoned to themselves, left to the chances of good or ill fortune.

column2: The Spider of the brushwood, on the contrary, endowed with greater maternal devotion, has, like the Crab Spider, to mount guard over hers until they hatch.
column3: The Spider of the brushwood, on the contrary, endowed with greater maternal devotion, has, like the Crab Spider, to mount guard over hers until they hatch.

column2: With a few threads and some small leaves joined together, the Crab Spider builds, above her lofty nest, a rudimentary watch-tower where she stays permanently, greatly emaciated, flattened into a sort of wrinkled shell through the emptying of her ovaries and the total absence of food.
column3: With a few threads and some small leaves joined together, the Crab Spider builds, above her lofty nest, a rudimentary watch tower where she stays permanently, greatly emaciated, flattened into a sort of wrinkled shell through the emptying of her ovaries and the total absence of food.

column2: And this mere shred, hardly more than a skin that persists in living without eating, stoutly defends her egg-sack, shows fight at the approach of any tramp.
column3: And this mere shred, hardly more than a skin that persists in living without eating, stoutly defends her egg sack, shows fight at the approach of any tramp.

column2: She does not make up her mind to die until the little ones are gone.
column3: She does not make up her mind to die until the little ones are gone.

column2: The Labyrinth Spider is better treated.
column3: The Labyrinth Spider is better treated.

column2: After laying her eggs, so far from becoming thin, she preserves an excellent appearance and a round belly.
column3: After laying her eggs, so far from becoming thin, she preserves an excellent appearance and a round belly.

column2: Moreover, she does not lose her appetite and is always prepared to bleed a Locust.
column3: Moreover, she does not lose her appetite and is always prepared to bleed a Locust.

column2: She therefore requires a dwelling with a hunting-box close to the eggs watched over.
column3: She therefore requires a dwelling with a hunting box close to the eggs watched over.

column2: We know this dwelling, built in strict accordance with artistic canons under the shelter of my cages.
column3: We know this dwelling, built in strict accordance with artistic canons under the shelter of my cages.

column2: Remember the magnificent oval guard-room, running into a vestibule at either end; the egg-chamber slung in the centre and isolated on every side by half a score of pillars; the front-hall expanding into a wide mouth and surmounted by a network of taut threads forming a trap.
column3: Remember the magnificent oval guard room, running into a vestibule at either end; the egg chamber slung in the centre and isolated on every side by half a score of pillars; the front hall expanding into a wide mouth and surmounted by a network of taut threads forming a trap.

column2: The semi-transparency of the walls allows us to see the Spider engaged in her household affairs.
column3: The semi transparency of the walls allows us to see the Spider engaged in her household affairs.

column2: Her cloister of vaulted passages enables her to proceed to any point of the star-shaped pouch containing the eggs. Indefatigable in her rounds, she stops here and there; she fondly feels the satin, listens to the secrets of the wallet.
column3: Her cloister of vaulted passages enables her to proceed to any point of the star shaped pouch containing the eggs. Indefatigable in her rounds, she stops here and there; she fondly feels the satin, listens to the secrets of the wallet.

column2: If I shake the net at any point with a straw, she quickly runs up to enquire what is happening. Will this vigilance frighten off the Ichneumon and other lovers of omelettes?
column3: If I shake the net at any point with a straw, she quickly runs up to enquire what is happening. Will this vigilance frighten off the Ichneumon and other lovers of omelettes?

column2: Perhaps so.
column3: Perhaps so.

column2: But, though this danger be averted, others will come when the mother is no longer there.
column3: But, though this danger be averted, others will come when the mother is no longer there.

column2: Her attentive watch does not make her overlook her meals.
column3: Her attentive watch does not make her overlook her meals.

column2: One of the Locusts whereof I renew the supply at intervals in the cages is caught in the cords of the great entrance-hall.
column3: One of the Locusts whereof I renew the supply at intervals in the cages is caught in the cords of the great entrance hall.

column2: The Spider arrives hurriedly, snatches the giddy-pate and disjoints his shanks, which she empties of their contents, the best part of the insect.
column3: The Spider arrives hurriedly, snatches the giddy pate and disjoints his shanks, which she empties of their contents, the best part of the insect.

column2: The remainder of the carcass is afterwards drained more or less, according to her appetite at the time.
column3: The remainder of the carcass is afterwards drained more or less, according to her appetite at the time.

column2: The meal is taken outside the guard-room, on the threshold, never indoors.
column3: The meal is taken outside the guard room, on the threshold, never indoors.

column2: These are not capricious mouthfuls, serving to beguile the boredom of the watch for a brief while; they are substantial repasts, which require several sittings.
column3: These are not capricious mouthfuls, serving to beguile the boredom of the watch for a brief while; they are substantial repasts, which require several sittings.

column2: Such an appetite astonishes me, after I have seen the Crab Spider, that no less ardent watcher, refuse the Bees whom I give her and allow herself to die of inanition.
column3: Such an appetite astonishes me, after I have seen the Crab Spider, that no less ardent watcher, refuse the Bees whom I give her and allow herself to die of inanition.

column2: Can this other mother have so great a need as that to eat?
column3: Can this other mother have so great a need as that to eat?

column2: Yes, certainly she has; and for an imperative reason.
column3: Yes, certainly she has; and for an imperative reason.

column2: At the beginning of her work, she spent a large amount of silk, perhaps all that her reserves contained; for the double dwelling--for herself and for her offspring--is a huge edifice, exceedingly costly in materials; and yet, for nearly another month, I see her adding layer upon layer both to the wall of the large cabin and to that of the central chamber, so much so that the texture, which at first was translucent gauze, becomes opaque satin.
column3: At the beginning of her work, she spent a large amount of silk, perhaps all that her reserves contained; for the double dwelling-for herself and for her offspring-is a huge edifice, exceedingly costly in materials; and yet, for nearly another month, I see her adding layer upon layer both to the wall of the large cabin and to that of the central chamber, so much so that the texture, which at first was translucent gauze, becomes opaque satin.

column2: The walls never seem thick enough; the Spider is always working at them.
column3: The walls never seem thick enough; the Spider is always working at them.

column2: To satisfy this lavish expenditure, she must incessantly, by means of feeding, fill her silk-glands as and when she empties them by spinning.
column3: To satisfy this lavish expenditure, she must incessantly, by means of feeding, fill her silk glands as and when she empties them by spinning.

column2: Food is the means whereby she keeps the inexhaustible factory going.
column3: Food is the means whereby she keeps the inexhaustible factory going.

column2: A month passes and, about the middle of September, the little ones hatch, but without leaving their tabernacle, where they are to spend the winter packed in soft wadding.
column3: A month passes and, about the middle of September, the little ones hatch, but without leaving their tabernacle, where they are to spend the winter packed in soft wadding.

column2: The mother continues to watch and spin, lessening her activity from day to day.
column3: The mother continues to watch and spin, lessening her activity from day to day.

column2: She recruits herself with a Locust at longer intervals; she sometimes scorns those whom I myself entangle in her trap.
column3: She recruits herself with a Locust at longer intervals; she sometimes scorns those whom I myself entangle in her trap.

column2: This increasing abstemiousness, a sign of decrepitude, slackens and at last stops the work of the spinnerets.
column3: This increasing abstemiousness, a sign of decrepitude, slackens and at last stops the work of the spinnerets.

column2: For four or five weeks longer, the mother never ceases her leisurely inspection-rounds, happy at hearing the new-born Spiders swarming in the wallet.
column3: For four or five weeks longer, the mother never ceases her leisurely inspection rounds, happy at hearing the new born Spiders swarming in the wallet.

column2: At length, when October ends, she clutches her offspring's nursery and dies withered.
column3: At length, when October ends, she clutches her offspring's nursery and dies withered.

column2: She has done all that maternal devotion can do; the special providence of tiny animals will do the rest.
column3: She has done all that maternal devotion can do; the special providence of tiny animals will do the rest.

column2: When spring comes, the youngsters will emerge from their snug habitation, disperse all over the neighbourhood by the expedient of the floating thread and weave their first attempts at a labyrinth on the tufts of thyme.
column3: When spring comes, the youngsters will emerge from their snug habitation, disperse all over the neighbourhood by the expedient of the floating thread and weave their first attempts at a labyrinth on the tufts of thyme.

column2: Accurate in structure and neat in silk-work though they be, the nests of the caged captives do not tell us everything; we must go back to what happens in the fields, with their complicated conditions.
column3: Accurate in structure and neat in silk work though they be, the nests of the caged captives do not tell us everything; we must go back to what happens in the fields, with their complicated conditions.

column2: Towards the end of December, I again set out in search, aided by all my youthful collaborators.
column3: Towards the end of December, I again set out in search, aided by all my youthful collaborators.

column2: We inspect the stunted rosemaries along the edge of a path sheltered by a rocky, wooded slope; we lift the branches that spread over the ground.
column3: We inspect the stunted rosemaries along the edge of a path sheltered by a rocky, wooded slope; we lift the branches that spread over the ground.

column2: Our zeal is rewarded with success.
column3: Our zeal is rewarded with success.

column2: In a couple of hours, I am the owner of some nests.
column3: In a couple of hours, I am the owner of some nests.

column2: Pitiful pieces of work are they, injured beyond recognition by the assaults of the weather!
column3: Pitiful pieces of work are they, injured beyond recognition by the assaults of the weather!

column2: It needs the eyes of faith to see in these ruins the equivalent of the edifices built inside my cages.
column3: It needs the eyes of faith to see in these ruins the equivalent of the edifices built inside my cages.

column2: Fastened to the creeping branch, the unsightly bundle lies on the sand heaped up by the rains.
column3: Fastened to the creeping branch, the unsightly bundle lies on the sand heaped up by the rains.

column2: Oak-leaves, roughly joined by a few threads, wrap it all round.
column3: Oak leaves, roughly joined by a few threads, wrap it all round.

column2: One of these leaves, larger than the others, roofs it in and serves as a scaffolding for the whole of the ceiling.
column3: One of these leaves, larger than the others, roofs it in and serves as a scaffolding for the whole of the ceiling.

column2: If we did not see the silky remnants of the two vestibules projecting and feel a certain resistance when separating the parts of the bundle, we might take the thing for a casual accumulation, the work of the rain and the wind.
column3: If we did not see the silky remnants of the two vestibules projecting and feel a certain resistance when separating the parts of the bundle, we might take the thing for a casual accumulation, the work of the rain and the wind.

column2: Let us examine our find and look more closely into its shapelessness. Here is the large room, the maternal cabin, which rips as the coating of leaves is removed; here are the circular galleries of the guard-room; here are the central chamber and its pillars, all in a fabric of immaculate white.
column3: Let us examine our find and look more closely into its shapelessness. Here is the large room, the maternal cabin, which rips as the coating of leaves is removed; here are the circular galleries of the guard room; here are the central chamber and its pillars, all in a fabric of immaculate white.

column2: The dirt from the damp ground has not penetrated to this dwelling protected by its wrapper of dead leaves.
column3: The dirt from the damp ground has not penetrated to this dwelling protected by its wrapper of dead leaves.

column2: Now open the habitation of the offspring.
column3: Now open the habitation of the offspring.

column2: What is this?
column3: What is this?

column2: To my utter astonishment, the contents of the chamber are a kernel of earthy matters, as though the muddy rain-water had been allowed to soak through.
column3: To my utter astonishment, the contents of the chamber are a kernel of earthy matters, as though the muddy rain water had been allowed to soak through.

column2: Put aside that idea, says the satin wall, which itself is perfectly clean inside.
column3: Put aside that idea, says the satin wall, which itself is perfectly clean inside.

column2: It is most certainly the mother's doing, a deliberate piece of work, executed with minute care.
column3: It is most certainly the mother's doing, a deliberate piece of work, executed with minute care.

column2: The grains of sand are stuck together with a cement of silk; and the whole resists the pressure of the fingers.
column3: The grains of sand are stuck together with a cement of silk; and the whole resists the pressure of the fingers.

column2: If we continue to unshell the kernel, we find, below this mineral layer, a last silken tunic that forms a globe around the brood.
column3: If we continue to unshell the kernel, we find, below this mineral layer, a last silken tunic that forms a globe around the brood.

column2: No sooner do we tear this final covering than the frightened little ones run away and scatter with an agility that is singular at this cold and torpid season.
column3: No sooner do we tear this final covering than the frightened little ones run away and scatter with an agility that is singular at this cold and torpid season.

column2: To sum up, when working in the natural state, the Labyrinth Spider builds around the eggs, between two sheets of satin, a wall composed of a great deal of sand and a little silk.
column3: To sum up, when working in the natural state, the Labyrinth Spider builds around the eggs, between two sheets of satin, a wall composed of a great deal of sand and a little silk.

column2: To stop the Ichneumon's probe and the teeth of the other ravagers, the best thing that occurred to her was this hoarding which combines the hardness of flint with the softness of muslin.
column3: To stop the Ichneumon's probe and the teeth of the other ravagers, the best thing that occurred to her was this hoarding which combines the hardness of flint with the softness of muslin.

column2: This means of defence seems to be pretty frequent among Spiders.
column3: This means of defence seems to be pretty frequent among Spiders.

column2: Our own big House Spider, _Tegenaria domestica_, encloses her eggs in a globule strengthened with a rind of silk and of crumbly wreckage from the mortar of the walls.
column3: Our own big House Spider, underscore Tegenaria domestica underscore, encloses her eggs in a globule strengthened with a rind of silk and of crumbly wreckage from the mortar of the walls.

column2: Other species, living in the open under stones, work in the same way.
column3: Other species, living in the open under stones, work in the same way.

column2: They wrap their eggs in a mineral shell held together with silk.
column3: They wrap their eggs in a mineral shell held together with silk.

column2: The same fears have inspired the same protective methods.
column3: The same fears have inspired the same protective methods.

column2: Then how comes it that, of the five mothers reared in my cages, not one has had recourse to the clay rampart?
column3: Then how comes it that, of the five mothers reared in my cages, not one has had recourse to the clay rampart?

column2: After all, sand abounded: the pans in which the wire-gauze covers stood were full of it.
column3: After all, sand abounded: the pans in which the wire gauze covers stood were full of it.

column2: On the other hand, under normal conditions, I have often come across nests without any mineral casing.
column3: On the other hand, under normal conditions, I have often come across nests without any mineral casing.

column2: These incomplete nests were placed at some height from the ground, in the thick of the brushwood; the others, on the contrary, those supplied with a coating of sand, lay on the ground.
column3: These incomplete nests were placed at some height from the ground, in the thick of the brushwood; the others, on the contrary, those supplied with a coating of sand, lay on the ground.

column2: The method of the work explains these differences.
column3: The method of the work explains these differences.

column2: The concrete of our buildings is obtained by the simultaneous manipulation of gravel and mortar.
column3: The concrete of our buildings is obtained by the simultaneous manipulation of gravel and mortar.

column2: In the same way, the Spider mixes the cement of the silk with the grains of sand; the spinnerets never cease working, while the legs fling under the adhesive spray the solid materials collected in the immediate neighbourhood.
column3: In the same way, the Spider mixes the cement of the silk with the grains of sand; the spinnerets never cease working, while the legs fling under the adhesive spray the solid materials collected in the immediate neighbourhood.

column2: The operation would be impossible if, after cementing each grain of sand, it were necessary to stop the work of the spinnerets and go to a distance to fetch further stony elements.
column3: The operation would be impossible if, after cementing each grain of sand, it were necessary to stop the work of the spinnerets and go to a distance to fetch further stony elements.

column2: Those materials have to be right under her legs; otherwise the Spider does without and continues her work just the same.
column3: Those materials have to be right under her legs; otherwise the Spider does without and continues her work just the same.

column2: In my cages, the sand is too far off.
column3: In my cages, the sand is too far off.

column2: To obtain it, the Spider would have to leave the top of the dome, where the nest is being built on its trellis-work support; she would have to come down some nine inches.
column3: To obtain it, the Spider would have to leave the top of the dome, where the nest is being built on its trellis work support; she would have to come down some nine inches.

column2: The worker refuses to take this trouble, which, if repeated in the case of each grain, would make the action of the spinnerets too irksome.
column3: The worker refuses to take this trouble, which, if repeated in the case of each grain, would make the action of the spinnerets too irksome.

column2: She also refuses to do so when, for reasons which I have not fathomed, the site chosen is some way up in the tuft of rosemary.
column3: She also refuses to do so when, for reasons which I have not fathomed, the site chosen is some way up in the tuft of rosemary.

column2: But, when the nest touches the ground, the clay rampart is never missing.
column3: But, when the nest touches the ground, the clay rampart is never missing.

column2: Are we to see in this fact proof of an instinct capable of modification, either making for decadence and gradually neglecting what was the ancestors' safeguard, or making for progress and advancing, hesitatingly, towards perfection in the mason's art?
column3: Are we to see in this fact proof of an instinct capable of modification, either making for decadence and gradually neglecting what was the ancestors' safeguard, or making for progress and advancing, hesitatingly, towards perfection in the mason's art?

column2: No inference is permissible in either direction.
column3: No inference is permissible in either direction.

column2: The Labyrinth Spider has simply taught us that instinct possesses resources which are employed or left latent according to the conditions of the moment.
column3: The Labyrinth Spider has simply taught us that instinct possesses resources which are employed or left latent according to the conditions of the moment.

column2: Place sand under her legs and the spinstress will knead concrete; refuse her that sand, or put it out of her reach, and the Spider will remain a simple silk-worker, always ready, however, to turn mason under favourable conditions.
column3: Place sand under her legs and the spinstress will knead concrete; refuse her that sand, or put it out of her reach, and the Spider will remain a simple silk worker, always ready, however, to turn mason under favourable conditions.

column2: The aggregate of things that come within the observer's scope proves that it were mad to expect from her any further innovations, such as would utterly change her methods of manufacture and cause her, for instance, to abandon her cabin, with its two entrance-halls and its star-like tabernacle, in favour of the Banded Epeira's pear-shaped gourd.
column3: The aggregate of things that come within the observer's scope proves that it were mad to expect from her any further innovations, such as would utterly change her methods of manufacture and cause her, for instance, to abandon her cabin, with its two entrance halls and its star like tabernacle, in favour of the Banded Epeira's pear shaped gourd.
